reviewText: I seriously don't understand all these glowing reviews here on amazon.  Left Bank stinks.  Not only was I not informed that you have to read subtitles throughout the movie (which plays a major part in destroying the atmosphere since I'm spending most of my time reading and less time noticing the facial expressions, social interaction and surroundings on screen) but... everything else about Left Bank falls flat on its face as well.The storyline revolves around a Portuguese girl who is an exceptional runner (fifth best in the world if I remember) and demands perfection of her talents, and has really graphic sex in numerous places as the camera isn't shy showing ANY of this.  Eventually she finds out she's pregnant, and throughout this bland mess of a storyline we never experience any horror, suspense or atmosphere ever.  She messes her knee up at one point and has to visit the doctor.  Are you scared or enticed yet?  Yeah, me neither.We do experience the everyday life of a pretty normal girl who has several ups and downs, however.  Perhaps the ending has a little bit of horror (and that's a big stretch- more like mild suspense) but none of this even comes close to any of the classic horror films so placing it in the same category as the Exorcist or Halloween is not only illogical, but laughable to me.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The best way I can describe LEFT BANK without giving anything away, is to describe how the ending made me feel. I felt the same way I did at the end of ROSEMARY'S BABY, THE OMEN, HOUSE OF THE DEVIL, THE SHRINE, and THE WICKER MAN. The story concerns a track runner named Marie (Eline Kuppens), and her journey into darkness and ritualistic doom. She meets a man named Bobby (Matthias Schoenaerts)) who seems like a wonderful guy. As the tale unfolds, Marie is caught up in a mystery that leads only to terror. The atmosphere of LEFT BANK is gloomy throughout its running time. It starts out very subtly, growing increasingly claustrophobic, until it drops the finale on you like a blanket of lead! Then, when all seems lost, it throws a twist that I never saw coming! A supremely positive twist to an otherwise -relentlessly- bleak film. If you enjoy supernatural conspiracy movies w/ an unexpected bang, then LEFT BANK belongs in your collection...  P.S.- Don't let anyone tell you about the ending! Then, watch it and see if it doesn't leave a mark (Dutch w/ subtitles)...

reviewText: If you're looking for gore and violence, this film isn't for you. What I liked about this bleak, belgian film are the subtlety and realism uncommon to horror movies about modern day sects and ancient cults. Suspense and uncertainty lead you slowly to the unexpected ending that shows us that we should never trust anybody and believe in the unbelievable.
summary: Subtle and Realistic Horror Film from Belgium
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Left Bank" comes dangerously close to being boring, with a boil so slow it sometimes reduces to a barely perceptible simmer. But there is just enough unease, and more than enough sexuality, to keep the viewer interested. Which turns out to be a good thing, because in the final act, things get crazy fast and the long-delayed payoff leaves the horror fan satisfied. It's not your typical Hollywood horror movie, where everything is fairly simple and programmatic, but much more of a character-driven and atmospheric film. In this it reminded me very much of the venerable horror classic, "Rosemary's Baby," although it draws on a different strain of mythology than the Antichrist myth. To say more would be to risk spoiling some pleasant surprises; suffice to say that if you have patience through the stage-setting earlier part (you will probably be kept entertained by the steamy eroticism--the director seemed to understand we needed SOMETHING visceral to keep us hooked), you will be rewarded with a slightly off-kilter but more familiar horror final act.

reviewText: Certainly, this horror-thriller has much in common with Robin Hardy's Wicker man" from 1973.But his director Pieter van Heees handles with absolute solvence the camera to tell us by stages, this cryptic tale that envolves murders related with pagan fertility rites.A sect established by devoted followers must offer a victim for getting fertility. Every seven years.Watch it, it will shock you. Good acting by Eline Kuppens.

reviewText: If you don't like slow-building suspense, you won't like this movie.  If you do like it and love to reach a rewarding climax, then you probably will.  The characters seem real enough and the movie always progresses forward and gives you small tastes of creepiness.  I can see why people compare it to Rosemary's baby but don't expect a completely similar ending.  I found the ending to be even better than I had expected.  I always enjoy a well-made foreign film and never found the subtitles to be overbearing.  It's not the best movie out there but it's got allot to enjoy.
